World-Honored One!

In our Buddha Dharma, the mind is the master, and all dharmas are not independent of the mind.

You now have great blessings and virtues at home, with plenty of jeweled necklaces, and your family members are safe and happy. You have right views and do not slander the Three Jewels. such a bhiká¹£u is not called one who has gone forth, is not a Å›ramaá¹‡a, not a brÄhmaá¹‡a, but merely has the appearance of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, with a mind always dwelling in the household life. Such a Å›ramaá¹‡a has no practice of detachment.
The practice of detachment has two kinds:
First, physical detachment.
Second, mental detachment.
As for physical seclusion, if a person goes forth and their body dwells in solitude, unstained by sensual desires, this is called physical seclusion.
If there are those who have gone forth and cultivate a pure mind, unstained by sensual desires, this is called mental seclusion.

Then the six groups of evil monks, upon hearing this Dharma sound, attained the forbearance of conformity.
However, although we now have faith in the Buddha's words, each of us still harbors doubts and has not reached a definitive understanding.
Excellent, World-Honored One!
You are able to sever all doubts in the world, have attained mastery over all dharmas, speak the truth, speak without duality, know the path, and reveal the path. We only pray that the TathÄgata!
For the sake of us and all sentient beings in the future, abandon expedient teachings and speak the true Dharma, forever free from doubt and regret, and enable us to enter the Buddha's path.

In this assembly there are two bodhisattvas, one a renunciant and the other a householder. These two bodhisattvas are well able to benefit and delight all sentient beings without rest. As I contemplate, the renunciant bodhisattva is not equal to the householder in cultivating the bodhisattva practice.
Why is this?

In the past there was a golden wheel-turning sage king who gave rise to the mind of supreme perfect enlightenment. Disgusted with the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and defilement of the world, he abandoned the position of wheel-turning sage king as if discarding a gob of spit, and with pure faith left home to enter the Buddha's path.

At that time, the eighty-four thousand palace ladies and concubines, seeing the king leave home, each gave rise to longing and beat their chests in loud wailing, giving rise to great distress. They experienced the suffering of separation from loved ones, like the suffering of hell.

When the sage king of the golden wheel first ascends the throne, the precious woman who responds to him, the king's thousand sons, ministers and retinue, together grieve at separation and abandon the throne to leave home. The sound of their weeping fills the four continents.
These relatives each say:
Our king's blessings and wisdom are immeasurable and boundless. How can he abandon us and leave home?
Alas! Alas! The world is empty and desolate. From now on we will have no support or reliance.

If there are pure and faithful sons and daughters of good family who take refuge in the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, arouse the bodhi mind, leave their parents and leave home to enter the Way, their parents' compassion and deep affection, the grief and sorrow of separation move heaven and earth, like fish in a dried-up stream writhing on the ground. The suffering of separation from loved ones is also like this, like the minds of the relatives of the wheel-turning king.
How can the renunciant bodhisattva, who benefits sentient beings, torment his parents and wife and children, causing countless people to suffer greatly?

For these reasons, a monastic bodhisattva has no compassion, no sympathy, and does not benefit sentient beings. Therefore, he is not like a lay bodhisattva who has great compassion, sympathizes with sentient beings, and benefits all.
At that time, the Buddha told the elder JÃ±Änaprabha:
Excellent, excellent!
You have great compassion and have encouraged me to explain the superiority and inferiority of the two types, monastics and laypeople.
What you have asked about, that a monastic bodhisattva is inferior to a lay bodhisattva,
is not so.
Why is it not so?
A monastic bodhisattva is superior to a lay bodhisattva, immeasurable, boundless, and incomparable.
Why is it so?

A monastic bodhisattva, with the power of right wisdom, minutely observes the various faults of a lay person, namely, in the world, all houses accumulate things in them without knowing satisfaction, just as the great ocean can contain all the large and small rivers without ever being satisfied.
Good man!

South of Fragrant Mountain and north of Snow Mountain is Lake Anavatapta, with the four great dragon kings each dwelling in one corner. The dragon king in the southeast has a white elephant head, the dragon king in the southwest has a large ox head, the dragon king in the northwest has a lion head, and the dragon king in the northeast has a large horse head. Each emerges from their respective corners and gives rise to a great river:
The first is the Ganges River, and wherever its waters reach, white elephants emerge.ğŸ”½The second is the Sindhu River, and wherever its waters reach, water buffaloes emerge.
The third is the Vakshu River, and wherever its waters reach, lions emerge.
The fourth is the SÄ«tÄ River, and wherever its waters reach, large horses emerge.

Each of these great rivers has five hundred medium-sized rivers, and each of the medium-sized rivers has innumerable small rivers. All these waters enter the great ocean, yet the great ocean is never satisfied.

The same is true for the dwellings of all sentient beings in the world. Treasures gather from all directions and enter the house, but they are never satisfied. Seeking more and more, accumulating and storing, one commits various crimes. When impermanence suddenly arrives, one abandons the old house. At that time, the owner of the house follows karma and receives retribution, passing through countless eons without ever returning.
Good man!
The house refers to the body of the five aggregates, and the owner of the house is your original consciousness.
Who has wisdom and delights in the conditioned house?
There is only the blissful jeweled palace of enlightenment, free from old age, sickness, death, worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress.

If there are those with sharp faculties, pure faith, and profound goodness, who wish to deliver their parents, spouse, children, and relatives, and cause them to enter the house of the sweet dew of the unconditioned, they must return to the Three Jewels, leave the household life, and study the path.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattva surpasses the householder, in terms of calculation and analogy, there is no comparison.
Being at home is oppressive like a prison, and it is very difficult to seek liberation.
Leaving the home life is vast and open like space, with freedom, no-action, and detachment from attachment.
Carefully observe that being at home has many faults, and one creates boundless evil karma.
Seeking to make a living, greedily grasping, one is always insufficient, just like the ocean which is difficult to fill.
The nÄga kings of Lake Anavatapta, from the four corners, spout forth the four great rivers,
The waters of the great, small, and medium rivers, flowing day and night without pause,
Yet the great ocean is never filled.
Being at home gives rise to many evil deeds, which are never washed away and eliminated,
In vain knowing to cherish this fragile body, not realizing that life follows the exhaustion of morning dew.
The messengers of Yama urge and press, with no wife, children, or house to follow,
In the long night of the dark and gloomy netherworld, alone going through the gate of death, following karma and receiving [its fruits].
The Buddhas appear out of compassion, wishing to cause sentient beings to be disgusted with the world,
You have now obtained a difficult-to-attain body, you should diligently cultivate and not be negligent.
The house of the layperson is deeply to be disliked, the precious house of emptiness and tranquility is inconceivable,
Forever free from illness, suffering, and worry, all wise ones should observe well.
In the future, pure faithful sons and daughters, wishing to liberate their parents and relatives,
To cause them to enter the city of the sweet dew of the unconditioned, vowing to leave the household life and cultivate the wonderful path,
Gradually practicing and attaining perfect enlightenment, they will turn the unsurpassed great Dharma wheel.
Furthermore, good man!
The renunciant bodhisattva observes the worldly house to be like a spark of fire, deeply giving rise to disgust and aversion.
Why is it so?
It is like a small fire that can burn all grasses and trees, and so it is with the worldly house. The greedy mind seeks and runs in the four directions.
If they obtain something, they are not satisfied with their enjoyment and pursue it endlessly at all times;
If they obtain nothing, their minds are tormented and they pursue it day and night.
Therefore, all houses in the world can give rise to immeasurable fires of afflictions and cause the mind of greed to be perpetually insatiable.
Worldly wealth and treasures are like grass and trees, and the mind of greed is like a worldly house. For this reason, all Buddhas speak of the three realms as a house on fire.
Good man!
The renunciant bodhisattva is able to contemplate in this way and is disgusted with the world, which is called true renunciation.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattva contemplates the worldly house, which is like a small fire in the human world,
Gradually able to burn all grass and trees. The worldly house should be known as such.
The various wealth and treasures possessed by sentient beings, pursuing each other, are always insufficient,
The suffering of not obtaining what is sought is always in the mind, and the fire of old age, sickness, and death never ceases.
For this reason, the World-Honored Ones say that the three realms are a burning house.
If one wishes to transcend the suffering of the three realms, one should cultivate the brahmacarya and become an ascetic,
Attain samÄdhi and spiritual powers, and perfect one's own benefit and benefiting others.
Moreover, good man!
One who delights in leaving the household life should contemplate the dwelling as being like a great treasure trove in the depths of a mountain cave.
It is like an elder who has only one son. His family is extremely wealthy with immeasurable treasures, and he has countless male and female servants, elephants, and horses.
Later, the father suddenly falls seriously ill, and the famous doctors and excellent medicines cannot save him.
The elder knows that his death is imminent, and he immediately summons his son and tells him:
'All the wealth and treasures I possess, I entrust to you. Guard them diligently and do not let them be lost.
Having entrusted it to him, he immediately passed away.

At that time, the elder's son did not follow his instructions, indulging in unrestrained behavior. He squandered the family business, lost his wealth and property, and his servants ran away, leaving him with nothing to rely on.
At that time, the old mother's heart was filled with worry and distress, and she eventually became seriously ill and passed away.
Her son, poor and destitute, had no one to rely on. He then went to the mountains and valleys, picking firewood and gathering fruits to sell for his own livelihood.

At that time, he encountered snow and entered a cave to rest for a while. In this cave, there were treasures from the past that the king had hidden there. No one knew about it, and for hundreds of thousands of years, no human traces were found.

At that time, due to the causes and conditions of his karma, the poor man happened to enter the cave and saw countless gold. His heart was filled with great joy, and he had never experienced such a thing before. He then divided the gold into several parts. With some of the gold, he built a house; with some of the gold, he took a wife; in this way, he had servants and elephants and horses, and everything he desired was just as he wished.

When he was making this calculation, there were some bandits chasing a running deer who came to the front of the cave. Seeing this poor man distributing gold, they abandoned the deer, killed the man, and took the gold.

Foolish ordinary people are also like this. Deeply attached to worldly pleasures, they do not enjoy liberation. The deep mountain cave is like a worldly house. The hidden gold and treasure is like good roots. The messengers of Yama are just like the bandits. Following karma, they receive retribution and fall into the three evil paths. They do not hear the names of parents and the Three Jewels. They lose their good roots. For this reason, one should become disgusted and give rise to the unsurpassed great bodhi mind. Renouncing the householder life, one cultivates the path, hoping to attain wondrous enlightenment.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The bodhisattvas who delight in the householder life regard their homes as treasure troves.
It is like an elder who has an only son. His family is very wealthy and has abundant treasures.
Male and female servants, elephants and horses, all necessities were abundant.
Later, the elder became ill, and all the world's good doctors gave up,
At the time of death, he entrusted his wealth to his son,
Teaching him to have a filial and caring heart, and to diligently make offerings without interruption.
At that time, the son disobeyed his father's instructions, indulging in foolishness and negligence,
The elderly mother was worried and sick, and because of the bad son, she soon passed away.
The relatives were scattered and had no one to rely on, making a living by collecting firewood and selling it,
Going to the mountains, they encountered wind and snow, and temporarily rested in a stone cave.
In the cave, there were wondrous treasures from the past, known to no one for a long time,
The woodcutter encountered the hidden true gold, his heart filled with joy and wonder.
They immediately distributed the real gold and jewels, using them as they wished,
Either building houses or wives and wealth, slaves, elephants, horses, and carriages.
Calculating the future, there was no one who could give up. A group of thieves came to their presence because of the deer,
When they met with their enemies, they ended up killing the poor man and taking the gold away.
Foolish beings are also like this. The stone cave is like a house in the world,
The hidden treasure of real gold is compared to wholesome roots. The Yama demons and messengers are like robbers.ğŸ”½For this reason, sons and daughters of the buddhas,
Early on, they go forth and cultivate wholesome practices.
They should contemplate the body and life as like floating bubbles, and diligently cultivate the pÄramitÄs of precepts and patience,
They should go to the seven-jeweled bodhi tree, and on the adamantine seat realize suchness,
Forever abiding and not perishing, difficult to fathom, turning the wheel of the true Dharma and transforming all beings.
Furthermore, good man!
All the houses in the world are like poisonous food with a sweet taste.

It is like an elder who has only one child, who is intelligent, sharp-witted, and has mastered the secret observation method of the garuá¸as, able to discern poisons and skillful in means, and whom his parents love with incomparable affection.
At that time, the elder's child, for the sake of some matter, went to the market and had not yet returned home.
At that time, his parents and relatives joyfully feasted and prepared delicious food.
At that time, an enemy secretly mixed poison into the food, and no one noticed.
At that time, the parents did not know that there was poisonous medicine mixed in the food, and so they made the young and old eat the food mixed with poisonous medicine;
When the child returned later, his parents joyfully gave him the remaining food.
At that time, the child did not need to eat, and he thought of the secret observation method of the garuá¸as, and then knew that there was poisonous medicine in the food.
Although the son knew that his parents had ingested poison, he did not tell them that they had mistakenly ingested poisonous medicine.
Why is it so?
If they were to realize they had ingested poison, they would become even more confused, and the poisonous qi would quickly spread, surely causing them to die.
He then devised a skillful means and said to his parents:
I will not eat such food for now. I will go to the market for a while and come back to eat.
Why is it so?
I previously bought an invaluable jewel and left it in the chest, forgetting to seal it.
Thereupon, the parents, hearing of the jewel, gave rise to a joyful mind and allowed their son to go as he wished.
The son then ran to the house of the king of physicians, seeking the agada wondrous medicine that cures poison.
Having obtained this medicine, he quickly ran home, mixed the agada with three flavors of milk, butter, and molasses, and made the medicine. Having done this, he said to his parents:
I only wish that my parents would take this nectar. This is the agada medicine from the Snow Mountains.
Why is it so?
The parents have mistakenly ingested poison. I have temporarily left to seek this wondrous medicine of immortality for the parents and all people.

' Then the parents and all the people were overjoyed, having never experienced such a thing before. They immediately ingested the wondrous medicine, vomited out all the poisonous air, and attained immortality, extending their life spans.

The renunciant bodhisattva is also like this. The parents of the past are submerged in birth and death, and the parents of the present are unable to escape. The future of birth and death is difficult to completely sever, and the present afflictions are difficult to subdue. For these reasons, in order to deliver the parents and all beings, they arouse the mind of great compassion that shares the same essence, seek great enlightenment, leave the home-life, and enter the path.
Good man!
This is called the house being like mixing poison into delicious food.

Intelligent, sharp-witted, and very talented,
Skilled in the secret methods of the garuá¸as, able to distinguish poisons and skillful in means.ğŸ”½The son has business elsewhere and goes to the market,
Temporarily trading and not yet returning home,
His parents are feasting and gathering relatives, with all kinds of delicacies fully provided.ğŸ”½A wicked person brings poisonous medicine,
Secretly adding it to the food and drink.ğŸ”½At that time, the son is not at home,
His parents leave a portion for their child,
The whole family mistakenly takes the mixed poisonous medicine.ğŸ”½The son contemplates the method and knows there is poison,ğŸ”½So he immediately runs to the doctor's place,
Seeking the immortal medicine of the gÄthÄ.ğŸ”½The three flavors are combined and boiled, the medicine is already complete,
Then he tells the relatives to quickly take it,ğŸ”½Thus, what is taken is like nectar,

All faithful sons and daughters, who leave the household life to cultivate the path, are also like this.
In order to save their parents and sentient beings, they ingest the poisonous medicines of afflictions,
And due to the inverted and deluded mind, they commit offenses, forever sinking in the ocean of suffering and sorrow of birth and death.
Cutting off love and leaving their parents to enter the Buddha's path, they get to be close to the great physician king who tames and guides,
And cultivate the uncontaminated agada medicine, returning to the house of the three realms of their parents,
Causing them to ingest the Dharma medicine and sever the three obstacles, and they will realize the unsurpassed fruit of enlightenment.
Extending to the end of the future, they are eternally extinguished, able to deliver sentient beings and become their refuge,
Ultimately dwelling in the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, and the perfect mirror wisdom of the Buddha's enlightenment.
Moreover, good sons!
The renunciant bodhisattva always observes all the houses in the world, just like a great wind that cannot stay still for a moment.
Why is it so?
Good sons!

The mind of a layperson always gives rise to false thoughts, attached to external objects, unable to understand the truth, deluded by the darkness of ignorance, and upside-down in touching objects, also always not abiding, evil thoughts easily arising, and the wholesome mind difficult to give rise to.

Because of false thoughts, various afflictions arise. Due to the many afflictions, one creates good and evil karma. Based on good and evil karma, one experiences the fruits of the five destinies. In this way, birth and death are unceasing.

Only those with right views and an upside-down mind create good karma. Due to the three roots of goodness and faith, etc., they increase the seeds of the dharmas that are not subject to birth and death and can give rise to the samÄdhi and spiritual powers that are not subject to birth and death.
In this way, they realize the continuity of the holy ones. If one subdues false thoughts and cultivates right contemplation, all afflictions will be eternally exhausted without remainder.
At that time, the elder JÃ±Änaprabha addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The cultivation of right contemplation has innumerable gates. Which contemplation can subdue false thoughts?
At that time, the World-Honored One told the elder:
Good sons!
You should cultivate the correct contemplation of signlessness.
The contemplation of signlessness can subdue false imagination, and only contemplate the true nature without seeing the ten signs.
All dharmas are originally empty and quiescent, without seeing and without knowing. This is called correct contemplation.

If a Buddha-son abides in correct mindfulness and contemplates in this way, cultivating signlessness and non-action for a long time, the fierce wind of false imagination will be still and unmoving, and the holy wisdom will manifest and realize the perfect completion of the principle.
Good sons!
This is called a sage, this is called a bodhisattva, and this is called the Tathagata's anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.

For these causes and conditions, all bodhisattvas, in order to subdue false imagination and never give rise to it, in order to repay the four kinds of kindness and accomplish the four virtues, leave the household life to cultivate and study, to still the mind of false imagination, and for immeasurable eons accomplish the Buddha way.
At that time, the Tathagata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattva observes the householder, like a violent wind that does not stay for a moment,
Also like falsely grasping at the moon in the water, discriminating and conceptualizing it as real.
The moon's reflection has never existed in the water, clear water serves as a condition to see the original moon,
All dharmas arise from conditions and are all false, the foolish and ignorant falsely conceive of them as a self.
This very dharma that arises from conditions is not real, conceptual discrimination falsely conceives of it as existent,
If one can eliminate the two attachments, one will realize the unsurpassed great enlightenment.
The deluded thoughts of ordinary beings are like a black wind, blowing the forest of birth and death up and down,
The ghosts of the four inverted views always follow after, causing one to create the causes for the five heinous crimes,
The three unwholesome roots manifest as entanglements, the cycle of birth and death continues on and on.
If a person hears the sÅ«tra and deeply believes and understands it, right view can eliminate the inverted mind,
The seeds of enlightenment are born moment by moment, and great wisdom, spiritual powers, and samÄdhi arise.
If one is able to cultivate profound and wondrous contemplation, the fruits of delusion, karma, and suffering will not arise.
Only contemplating the true nature of reality, the nature of suchness, both subject and object are absent, free from all views.
The characteristics of male and female are originally empty, and the two characteristics arise due to deluded attachment.
The TathÄgata has permanently severed the causes of delusion, and the true nature is originally without the characteristics of male and female.
The wondrous fruit of enlightenment is realized as the same, but deluded thoughts give rise to different characteristics in ordinary beings.
The thirty-two marks are originally not marks; understanding that marks are not marks is the true mark.
If a person goes forth and cultivates pure conduct, concentrating the mind in tranquil seclusion,
This is the true pure mind of a bodhisattva, and before long they will realize the fruit of enlightenment.
Moreover, good man!
The renunciant bodhisattva always observes that in the world, all houses are places where afflictions arise.
Why is this?
It is like a person who builds eight houses, adorning them with various precious things.
Having built these houses, he thinks:
'Now these houses belong to me and do not belong to others. Only my houses are most auspicious, and other people's houses cannot compare.'

In this way, attachment gives rise to afflictions. Due to afflictions, the view of self and mine arises as the root. The eighty-four thousand gateways of dust and afflictions compete with each other and fill the houses.
Why is this?

Householders and ordinary people deeply attached to the five desires, with wives, children, relatives, servants, and maids all complete, due to these causes and conditions, they experience the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress, encountering what is disliked and being separated from what is loved, poverty and decline, the suffering of not obtaining what is sought - such various sufferings follow the body like a shadow, responding to sound like an echo, continuing from one life to the next, never ceasing.
Such various sufferings are not without causes, with the afflictions, whether grave or minor, as their fundamental basis;
All wealth and treasures are obtained through pursuit. If there are no prior causes, they cannot be pursued. Even if pursued, there will be nothing to gain.
Good man!
For this reason, all afflictions have pursuit as their basis. If pursuit is eliminated, innumerable afflictions will all be completely severed.
However, this body is the basis of various sufferings. The wise should give rise to disgust, just as in the past, Kashyapa Tathagata spoke a verse for the birds and beasts, saying:
This body is the root of suffering, the remaining sufferings are the branches and leaves,
If one can cut off the root of suffering, all sufferings will be eliminated.
Your past karma, creating offenses without remorse in your mind,
Results in an unlovable body experiencing various sufferings.
If you arouse a sincere mind and repent for a single thought,
Like fire burning a marsh, all offenses will be extinguished.
This body is suffering and impure, without self and impermanent,
You should all deeply give rise to a mind of disgust and detachment.'

At that time, the immeasurable various birds and beasts, having heard these verses, repented with a sincere mind in a single thought, then abandoned the evil destinies and were reborn in the fourth heaven, where they venerated the bodhisattva who is only one birth away from Buddhahood, heard the irreversible Dharma, and ultimately attained nirvana.
Good man!
For this reason, this painful body is like a house, and all afflictions are the owners of the house.

Therefore, the sons and daughters of good family who have pure faith, who give rise to the bodhi mind, leave the household life and enter the path, will certainly attain liberation from all suffering, and will all accomplish anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattva always observes the afflictions born from the house.
It is like a person who builds a house, adorns it with various precious treasures,
Thinking to himself that it is magnificent and incomparable, belonging to no one but himself,
The craftsmanship is most exquisite, and no house in the world can match it.
In this way, discrimination gives rise to attachment, with self and what belongs to self as the basis,
The eighty-four thousand afflictions fill the house, causing calamities.
All the men and women in the world, their six relations and relatives are all perfect,
Because of this, they give rise to various sufferings, namely birth, old age, sickness, and death,
Sorrow, grief, and suffering always follow, like a shadow following a form, never leaving for a moment.
The cause of all suffering arises from craving, if one cuts off pursuit, all suffering ends,
This body can be the root of all suffering, diligently practicing detachment, one aspires for enlightenment.
The body and mind of the three realms are like a house, the lord of afflictions dwells in the middle of the house,
You should give rise to the bodhi mind, abandon the ordinary person and leave the three realms.
Moreover, good sons!

The renunciant bodhisattva always observes the householder as if in a great country there is a wealthy elder, his family is rich and has immeasurable wealth and treasures, for many kalpas the father and son have inherited the causes and conditions without interruption, cultivating various wholesome practices, their fame is heard far and wide.
The great elder divided all his wealth and treasures into four parts:ğŸ”½One part of the wealth and treasures was always used to seek interest to support the family business;
One part of the wealth and treasures was used to provide for daily needs;ğŸ”½One part of the wealth and treasures was given to orphans and the poor to cultivate future blessings;
One part of the wealth and treasures was used to rescue relatives and guests from afar.
In this way, the four parts were never interrupted, and father and son succeeded each other as the family business.

Later, there was a son who was foolish, evil, deeply attached to the five desires, and indulged in recklessness. He went against his parents' teachings and did not follow the four occupations. He built houses with seven-story towers, twice the usual size, adorned with various treasures. The floors were made of lapis lazuli, with jeweled windows reflecting each other. Dragons' heads and fish shapes were all complete. Exquisite music played day and night without interruption. He enjoyed the pleasures of the five desires like the gods in the Heaven of the Thirty-three. Ghosts and spirits hated him, and humans and gods stayed far away.
Then a fire suddenly broke out in the neighboring house, the fierce flames raging and spreading with the wind, burning the storehouses and towers.

At that time, the elder's son, seeing this fierce fire, gave rise to great anger. He quickly ordered his wife, children, servants, and relatives to enter the multi-storied building and closed the doors of the towers. Due to his foolishness, they all died together.

Householders are also like this. Worldly fools are like the elder's son. The buddhas are like the elder. Not following the Buddha's teachings, they create evil karma and fall into the three evil paths, suffering greatly.
For this reason, the renunciant bodhisattva should observe householders, like the elder's son who did not follow his parents and was burned by the fire, with his wife and children dying together.
Good men and others!
You should give rise to disgust for the worldly and heavenly pleasures, cultivate pure conduct, and realize enlightenment.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattva observes the householder, just as an elder gives birth to a foolish son.
The family is wealthy with various treasures, passed down for a long time without lack,
The family business of past lives is passed down to the descendants, all the assets are divided into four parts.
Always cultivating superior practices without fault or evil, the reputation fills all countries,
The precious treasures of gold and silver are countless, the profits from buying and selling spread to other countries,
With a mind of loving-kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity without weariness, the giving of alms to the orphaned and poor is always uninterrupted.
The elder finally gives birth to a son, foolish, unfilial, and lacking wisdom,
As he grows old and his strength declines, he entrusts his family wealth inside and outside to his son.
The son disobeys his father's orders and acts recklessly, failing to carry on the family business in the four occupations,
He builds a precious seven-storied tower, using lapis lazuli for the windows and doors,
Singing, playing flutes and strings never ceased, always using unwholesome things to guide the mind,
Enjoying the five desires and pleasures like in the heavenly palace, all dragons and spirits stayed far away.
Suddenly a fire broke out in the neighboring house, the raging flames following the wind, difficult to stop,
The treasures in the storehouses, as well as the wife and children, the multi-storied buildings and houses were all burned down,
Accumulating evil leads to misfortune, eventually destroying the body, the wife, children, and relatives all perished together.
The Buddhas of the three times are like the elder, all ordinary beings are foolish children,
Not practicing the right path, giving rise to wrong thoughts, at the end of life falling into the evil destinies,
Alone enduring the suffering of burning for eons, such is the endless cycle.
Buddha's disciples in the household should know, not greedy for worldly pleasures, diligently practicing and realizing,
Disgusted with the world, leaving home to cultivate pure conduct, the mountains and forests are tranquil, free from all conditions,
In order to repay the four kinds of kindness and cultivate supreme virtues, I shall become the Dharma King of the three realms.
Until the end of the future, I shall liberate sentient beings, always speaking the Dharma as an unsolicited friend,
Forever severing the flow of craving and transcending to the other shore, dwelling in the pure city of nirvana.
Furthermore, good man!
The renunciant bodhisattva observes all the houses in the world as if in a great dream.
It is like a wealthy man who has a young girl, just fifteen years old, upright and extremely beautiful.

At that time, her parents were on a three-story tower, enjoying the pleasures of love with their beloved daughter. In the middle of the night, the mother and daughter slept together on a jeweled bed, peacefully resting.

Then the young woman dreamed that her parents betrothed her to a husband's family. After many years, she gave birth to a son who was upright and extremely wonderful, with the marks of wisdom. He gradually grew up and was able to walk on his own. He was in a high tower, and fell down in danger, but before he reached the ground, he was seen to be taken and eaten by a starving tiger.
At that time, the young woman was even more frightened and cried out in grief. She then suddenly woke up from the dream.
At that time, her parents asked her,
For what reason did you suddenly become frightened?
At that time, the young woman was ashamed and did not want to tell them.
Her mother earnestly asked her in secret about the reason.
At that time, the young woman secretly told her mother about the dream she had just had.
Good man!

In the world, the dwelling of birth and death is conditioned, and one always dwells in cyclic existence without attaining true awakening. In that state, one always dwells in dreams, in the dwelling of the three realms of birth, old age, sickness, and death.
Just like that young girl in a dream, false discrimination is also like this.
The messengers of the demon Yama suddenly arrive, like that hungry tiger in the sky snatching that infant and devouring it.
The impermanence, old age, sickness, and death of all sentient beings are also like this.
Who among the wise would love and delight in this body?

For these reasons, contemplating the long night of birth and death as a dream, one gives rise to the bodhi mind and disgusts the world, and will attain the wonderful fruit of the TathÄgata's eternal abiding.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
Buddha's disciples who seek the unsurpassed path should contemplate the dwelling as if in a dream.
It is like a wealthy and noble elder who has a young daughter who is wonderfully beautiful.
Following her parents, she goes up to a tall building, and watching and frolicking there, she is very happy.
The girl in the building has this dream: clearly in the dream, she marries another man,
Later, in her husband's home, she gave birth to a son, and his mother loved and pitied him with all her heart.
The son climbed to the tower and indulged in joy, and then fell into a tiger's mouth from the danger,
And so he lost his voice and woke up from the dream, only then realizing that the dream was originally not real.
The darkness of ignorance is like a long night, and before attaining perfect enlightenment it is like in a dream,
The world of birth and death is always unreal, and conceptual discrimination is also like this.
Only the four great bright wisdoms can be called true and wondrous enlightenment.
Impermanence moment by moment is like a starving tiger, conditioned phenomena are false and cannot last long,
Like birds at dawn flying in different directions.
When life ends and one is separated from others, it is also like this. Coming and going, abiding in karma, receiving various retributions, the kindness of parents is not recognized.
Alas! The mortal body in birth and death, transmigrating through the three paths and enduring suffering for a long time,
If one knows that good and evil are experienced according to karma, one should repent and eliminate them.
All the wonderful fruits of happiness in the human and heavenly realms are caused by a sense of shame and right views.
One should give rise to the firm bodhi mind, don the armor of diligence, and diligently cultivate and study.
Furthermore, good sons!

The renunciant bodhisattva observes the dwelling place to be like the mare's mouth ocean, which gives rise to raging flames that swallow the four great rivers and all the hundreds of streams, burning them all to the point of exhaustion.
It is like in the past in the country of Ratha, there was a bodhisattva named SubhavyÅ«ha. This bodhisattva had a compassionate mind and always harbored beneficence.

There were merchants who entered the ocean to collect treasures, and they took this bodhisattva on board their ship. They all reached the treasure island and crossed the perilous path, without any obstruction, and reached the other shore.
Later, the bodhisattva gradually grew old, already a hundred years old, and when getting up or sitting, he had to rely on support, unable to move forward on his own.
There was a caravan leader who went to where the Bodhisattva was, made obeisance and offered worship, and said to the Bodhisattva:
I wish to enter the ocean to seek precious treasures, forever leaving poverty and attaining great wealth and nobility.
Now I invite the Bodhisattva to go with me.
At that time, the Bodhisattva said to the caravan leader:
I am now old and decrepit, with little strength and unable to enter the ocean.
The caravan leader said again:
I only wish that the Great Being!
Do not abandon your compassion and pity, and accept my invitation. Just sit at ease in my ship. This is my wish.
At that time, the Bodhisattva accepted the merchant's invitation and boarded a large ship to enter the great ocean, heading southeast to the treasure site.

At that time, encountering a north wind, they drifted into the South Sea. The fierce wind was swift, not stopping day or night for seven days. They saw the water of the great ocean turn into golden color, like molten gold.
At that time, the merchants said to the Bodhisattva:
'What causes and conditions have caused the water to change to golden color and have such appearances?'
The Bodhisattva said:
'You should know that I have now entered the golden great ocean. Immeasurable and boundless purple gold fills the great ocean, and the golden treasure reflects each other, having such appearances.
Exceeding the right path, falling into this ocean, each of you should diligently seek and devise means to return to the north.'
After several more days, they saw the water of the great ocean change to white, like white jade or snow. The Bodhisattva said:
'You should know that I have now entered the great ocean of pearls. White jade pearls fill the ocean, and the pearls reflect the color of the water, having such appearances.
You should exert all your strength and devise means to return to the north.'
After several more days, the water of the great ocean changed to blue, like blue lapis lazuli. The Bodhisattva said:
'We and you have already entered the blue beryl sea. Countless blue beryl jewels fill the great ocean, and the color of the beryl reflects like this.'
After several more days, the water of the great ocean turned red like blood. The Bodhisattva said:

'We and you have already entered the red beryl sea. Countless red beryl jewels fill the great ocean, and the true color is red like this.'ğŸ”½After several more days, the water turned black like ink. From afar, one could hear the fierce sound of exploding fire, like a great fire burning dry bamboo groves, blazing and terrifying, such appearances had never been seen or heard before.

And seeing a great fire rising in the south, like a peak more than a hundred feet high, the flames flying through the air sometimes merging and sometimes dispersing, the light streaming like lightning, such appearances had never been seen or heard.
'Our lives are truly difficult to preserve.'
Then the Bodhisattva said to the people:
'You are now very frightened.
Why is that?
We have already entered the mare's mouth ocean. All the four great oceans and the large and small rivers of the four continents that flow into the northern ocean will be burned to the end.
Why is it so?
Due to the power of the increased karma of sentient beings, the heavenly fire naturally burns the seawater.
If this heavenly fire does not burn the seawater, in one day and night, all the land will turn into a great ocean, and all sentient beings will be drowned.
But now we have encountered a great black wind, drifting like this in the mare's mouth ocean. Our remaining lives are few.'
At that time, there were more than a thousand people on the ship, who all cried out in grief and wept, some pulling out their hair, some throwing themselves down, saying:
'We are now seeking precious treasures and have entered the great ocean, encountering this danger. Alas, alas!
By what means can we escape this difficulty?'

Then the thousand people, with utmost sincerity, took refuge, some calling out to the Compassionate Mother, some calling out to the Loving Father, some calling out to Brahma, some calling out to Mahesvara, the King of Gods, some calling out to the powerful Narayana, and some taking refuge in the Bodhisattva Who Attains the Other Shore. They paid homage to the great being and said:
'We only wish that the Bodhisattva will save us.'
At that time, the Bodhisattva, in order to free these people from all fear, spoke a verse, saying:
The supreme great man in the world, though entering the gate of death, does not give rise to fear.
If you lose wisdom due to sorrow and lamentation, you should single-mindedly devise skillful means.
If you attain the skillful means, you will leave behind the eight difficulties and transcend to the other shore.
Therefore, rest your mind and do not worry or fear, you should earnestly think of the Great Compassionate Honored One.'
Then, after the Bodhisattva had spoken this verse, he burned various famous incense, made obeisance, and made offerings to the Buddhas of the ten directions, and made this vow:

'Homage to the Buddhas of the ten directions, homage to the Buddhas of the ten directions, to the great Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva assembly, the four directions and four fruits, all sages, those with the heavenly eye, those with the heavenly ear, those who know others' minds, and those with various kinds of mastery. I, for the sake of sentient beings, with a mind of great compassion, abandon my life to save them from suffering and difficulty.
Now, I have one wholesome root. I uphold the TathÄgata's precept of not speaking falsely, and for innumerable lives, I have never violated it.
If in one life I have spoken falsely, then this evil wind will increase even more;
If this virtue of the precepts is not false, I vow to give this goodness to all, and I and sentient beings will attain Buddhahood.'

If it is true and not false, may this evil wind cease immediately, and may the favorable wind come as I wish. All sentient beings are my own body, and sentient beings and I are equal without distinction.'

When this great bodhisattva gave rise to such an unobstructed vow of great compassion that identifies with all beings, in an instant the evil wind ceased, and he immediately obtained a favorable wind, was liberated from various difficulties, reached the place of treasures, and obtained various precious treasures.
At that time, the bodhisattva told the merchants:

'Such precious treasures are difficult to encounter. You have widely practiced generosity in your past lives and have encountered such wonderful precious treasures. When cultivating generosity in the past, your mind was stingy. Due to this cause and condition, you encountered this evil wind.
You merchants should know the proper amount of precious treasures to obtain and not take too much, lest your greedy mind lead to great difficulties later.
You should know that among all treasures, the treasure of life is the most precious. If you preserve your life, it is a priceless treasure.'
At that time, the merchants, following the Bodhisattva's instruction, became content and did not dare take too much.
Then, the people escaped from the disaster, obtained great treasures, were far from poverty, and reached the other shore.
Good men!

The renunciant bodhisattvas are also like this. They are close to the buddhas, good friends and acquaintances, like those merchants who met the bodhisattvas, forever leaving birth and death and reaching the other shore, just like the caravan leader who obtained great wealth and nobility.
All the conditioned dwellings in the world are like the mare-mouth ocean that can burn all the waters.
The renunciant bodhisattvas are also like this. They carefully observe the faults of living at home.

You good men are not tainted by the five desires and pleasures of the world, are disgusted with the suffering and difficulties of birth and death in the three realms, and can enter the cool and blissful great city.
At that time, the TathÄgata spoke a verse again, saying:
The renunciant bodhisattvas observe dwellings, like the mare-mouth ocean burning all the waters.
It is like in the past, in the country of RÄjagá¹›ha, there was a bodhisattva named PrÄptakÅ«la,
Endowed with great merit, wisdom, skillful means, and unconditional compassion to embrace sentient beings,
This bodhisattva boarded a ship, and the merchants obtained treasures and crossed to the other shore.
However, this great being was old and decrepit, not enjoying benefiting others but preferring meditative tranquility.
There was a merchant leader who invited the bodhisattva, wishing to enter the great ocean to seek precious treasures,
'I only wish that the great being would accept my invitation, so that I may be wealthy and not lack anything.'
Then the bodhisattva, activating great compassion, immediately accepted the invitation and boarded the ship.
At that time, hoisting the large sails and encountering a favorable wind, they went straight to the southeast to the place of treasures,
But suddenly encountering a violent wind blowing the ship, they drifted into the South Sea, confused about where they were going.
After seven days, the water of the great ocean all turned into golden color,
The purple gold and yellow fills the ocean, and the reflected light manifests the true golden color.
After several more days, the water of the great ocean changes to white like conches and snow,
And precious pearls and gems fill the ocean, causing the seawater to turn white.
After several more days, the water of the great ocean changes to dark blue like lapis lazuli,
And blue glass beads fill the great ocean, causing the water to turn dark blue.
After several more days, the water of the great ocean all changes to red like vermilion,
And vermilion glass beads fill the ocean, causing the water to change color to match them.
After several more days, the water of the great ocean changes to black like ink,
Thus, burned by the heavenly fire, the seawater all turns black like ink.
This ocean is called the Mare's Mouth, swallowing the four oceans and all the rivers,
All ships that passed by, if people arrived here, many of them died.
The heavenly fire was blazing like a mountain, with explosive sounds like thunder.
The people saw it from afar, their hearts were terrified, they cried out and beat their chests, addressing the great teacher.
Then the Bodhisattva gave rise to compassion, not sparing his life, and extended his protection.
The violent wind soon stopped and a favorable wind arose, crossing the perilous path and reaching the treasure place.
Each obtained precious treasures and reached the other shore, forever leaving poverty and suffering, and receiving peace and happiness.
The renunciant Bodhisattva is also like this, closely following the Buddhas like a caravan leader,
Forever leaving the burning house and heading towards true enlightenment, like merchants returning to their original place.
All the houses in the world are like the mare-mouth ocean;
The renunciant always dislikes the householder, unstained by the world, leaving the five desires.
Delighting in dwelling in solitude, the mind unmoved, skillfully penetrating the profound and true wondrous principle,
Sometimes dwelling in the human realm or villages, like a bee gathering flowers without causing harm.
In the four deportments always benefiting beings, not greedy for worldly pleasures or fame,
Constantly emitting gentle sounds from the mouth, cutting off coarse, vulgar, and evil words,
Knowing gratitude and repaying kindness, cultivating wholesome karma, oneself and others both attaining the true and eternal.

Excellent, World-Honored One!
Marvellous, Well-Gone One!
It is just as you have said.
The subtle and supreme skillful means of benefiting beings as spoken by the World-Honored One,

We now understand all as spoken by the Buddha. The worldly home is like a prison. All evil dharmas arise from the home. For those who have left the home, there are truly innumerable and boundless benefits.
Therefore, we deeply enjoy leaving the household life and will always enjoy the Dharma in the present and future.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the elders:
Excellent, excellent!

If good men and good women give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment and leave the household life for even one day and night to cultivate the path, for two million eons they will not fall into evil destinies but will always be born in good places and experience supreme bliss. They will encounter good and virtuous friends and never regress, and will have the opportunity to meet the buddhas, receive predictions of enlightenment, sit on the vajra seat, and attain perfect enlightenment.
However, for those who leave the household life, upholding the precepts is the most difficult. Those who can uphold the precepts are true renunciants.
At that time, the elders said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

We uphold the precepts and cultivate pure practices, wishing to quickly escape the suffering of the sea of birth and death, wishing to quickly enter the palace of eternal bliss, wishing to widely deliver all sentient beings, wishing to quickly realize the wisdom of non-arising.

Thus, the elder entrusts you all to encourage him to leave the household life and uphold the pure precepts.
Then, nine thousand people, in front of Maitreya, left the household life to cultivate the path and uphold the Buddha's precepts.
Seven thousand people together, in front of MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, left the household life to cultivate the path and uphold the Buddha's prohibitions.
In this way, after these people had left the household life, they accomplished the acceptance of the Dharma and entered the TathÄgata's secret realm, never regressing again.
